awd_titl_txt: TC: Small: Integrating Privacy Preserving Biometric Templates and Efficient Indexing Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Biometrics, such as fingerprints, provide a great tool for personalized authentication. While people are usually willing to submit their biometric information to government agencies, they are less likely to do so for commercial companies without a guarantee of privacy protection. This project will have significant societal impact by triggering wide acceptability of large-scale biometrics enabled applications.
The primary technological hurdle faced by large scale biometric systems today is the ability to address two competing objectives: (1) provide fast matching of a biometric against a large database of stored biometric readings and (2) provide privacy of the biometrics in the database such that it can withstand malicious attacks. Existing solutions tackle either of the two problem but not both simultaneously.
Tackling the two problems in an integrated fashion is non-trivial as any solution to conceal the biometric data to ensure privacy involves breaking down the structure inherent in the biometric template, thus making it extremely challenging to index the records efficiently. This project presents a unified approach by developing "cryptographically hidden" biometric templates which will lend themselves to fast searches. This effort will draw upon new research in the fields of biometrics, databases, and coding theory.

por.por_cntn:
Passwords are ubiquitous in their use as an authentication mechanism. Passwords are stored securely on servers by using a secure hash function. On the other hand, it is very easy for a user to forget their password leading to a lot of angst and "Forgot Password" links (or even worse users choosing very simple passwords that they can remember but are conversely easier to hack). Fingerprints have the advantage that they are hard to "forget." On the other hand, there are technical hurdles in designing secure hash functions for fingerprints. In particular, the hash functions used for passwords fail miserably for fingerprints. (In short, hash functions for passwords need the exact same password to be entered to allow access while it is physically impossible to get the exact same reading more than once from a fingerprint scanner.)

In this project, we designed a few secure hash functions for fingerprints. Our contributions are two-fold. First we showed how one can exploit the inherent geometry of the fingerprint to design a secure hash function that gives reasonable matching accuracy while at the same time providing some security guarantees. Second, we showed how one can improve upon an existing hash function called "fuzzy vault" by removing certain known vulnerabilities of this hash function as well as provide a new security proof that is applicable in parameters used in practice (while previous security proofs in the practical regime did not give anything useful).

The project has trained one graduate and five undergraduate students. The graduate student will start as a lecturer in the CSE department at SUNY Buffalo. The undergraduate researchers have since then moved on to full time jobs at the Sandia Labs in NM and as a math high school teacher as well as to graduate school in Columbia, NYU and Buffalo.
